repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4936

A few notes on the implementation:
* I looked at both `<double>**<double>` and `<int>**<int>` since they're the points where it differs from Python.
* `<int>**<int>` now usually returns a double (unless it knows the exponent is non-negative)
* `<double>**<double>` returns a special type (a slightly overloaded complex double, with extra coercion rules to make it convertable to double/float when the imaginary part is 0). This is a little more complicated that just returning a py_object but keeps everything typed mostly in C so should be faster.
* By necessity https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5014 is included.
* I also softened type inference to complex types a little since it seemed worth trying.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            self.operand1.has_constant_result()
```
Also in some other places.

+/////////////// SoftComplexToDouble.proto //////////////////
+
+static double __Pyx_SoftComplexToDouble(__pyx_t_double_complex value); /* proto */
+
+/////////////// SoftComplexToDouble //////////////////
+//@requires: RealImag
+
+static double __Pyx_SoftComplexToDouble(__pyx_t_double_complex value) {
+    // This isn't an absolutely perfect match for the Python behaviour:
+    // In Python the type would be determined right after the number is
+    // created (usually '**'), while here it's determined when coerced
+    // to a PyObject, which may be a few operations later.
+    if (__Pyx_CIMAG(value)) {

comment_data.body: From reading this, it's not always clear where a distinction is made between the True/False cases and where you relate to something being positive, negative or complex for triggering a certain behaviour. Could you tear that a little more apart?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -864,6 +864,24 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     division is performed with negative operands.  See `CEP 516
     <https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/enhancements-division>`_.  Default is
     False.
+    
+``cpow`` (True / False)
+    ``cpow`` has two effects on the behaviour of ``a**b``.
+    
+    #. If both types are C integers then setting ``cpow`` to True 
+       forces the result type to be an integer. Otherwise the result 
+       type is a C floating point number if ``b`` can't be determined
+       to definitely be positive (the False case deviates from Python
+       slightly, since Python will dynamically pick either a Python
+       ``int`` or a Python ``float``).
+    #. If either or ``a`` or ``b`` is a floating point type then
+       setting ``cpow`` to True forces the result type to be a C
+       double, with a value of ``NaN`` if the result would be a
+       complex number. Otherwise the result can be either a real or
+       a complex number, at the cost of some speed.

comment_data.body:
Cautious proposal for clearer name - "soft complex" is IMO quite self-descriptive (and appears in several places), so why not use it for naming?

```suggestion

```

comment_data.body: Echoing @scoder's question, the first point currently reads like `cpow=True` is closer to python defaults (int ** int == int), so it's a bit surprising that the new default in cython 3.0 -- `cpow=False` -- is (seemingly) moving further away from python semantics.

comment_data.body:
At first (& second) glance, that inner `needs_widening` looks unreachable. On third thought I guess it isn't due to the various `or`-combinations in the initial if-condition.

Perhaps it would be easier to reason about (even if perhaps the code gets slightly longer) to separate the treatment of a conscious choice of nondefault `@cpow` from the could-the-result-be-complex inference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12249,9 +12269,36 @@ def analyse_c_operation(self, env):
                             (self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type))
 
     def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
-        c_result_type = super(PowNode, self).compute_c_result_type(type1, type2)
-        if isinstance(self.operand2.constant_result, _py_int_types) and self.operand2.constant_result < 0:
-            c_result_type = PyrexTypes.widest_numeric_type(c_result_type, PyrexTypes.c_double_type)
+        c_result_type = None
+        op1_is_definitely_positive = (
+            self.operand1.constant_result is not not_a_constant
+            and self.operand1.constant_result >= 0
+        ) or (
+            type1.is_int and type1.signed == 0  # definitely unsigned
+        )
+        type2_is_int = type2.is_int or (
+            self.operand2.constant_result is not not_a_constant and
+            int(self.operand2.constant_result) == self.operand2.constant_result
+        )
+        # if type2 is an integer than we can't end up going from real to complex
+        if self.cpow or op1_is_definitely_positive or type2_is_int:
+            c_result_type = super(PowNode, self).compute_c_result_type(type1, type2)
+            if self.operand2.constant_result is not_a_constant:
+                needs_widening = not self.cpow and type2.is_int and type2.signed
+                if needs_widening:
+                    self.cpow_false_changed_result_type = True

comment_data.body:
I really do mean ``b`` here. e.g. (in both Python and here) `2**(-2)` returns a `float`, while `2**2` returns an integer.

I'll have a go at rewriting this documentation though - it's clearly causing confusion.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
#. ``a**b`` of one or more non-complex floating point numbers may
   return a complex number.
```

Will push this change next time - don't think it justifies rerunning the CI on its own though
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -239,3 +239,16 @@ When running into an error it is required to add the corresponding operator::
         Example operator++(int)
         Example operator--(int)
 
+
+``**`` power operator
+=====================
+
+Cython 3 has changed the behaviour of the power operator to be
+more like Python. The consequences are that
+
+#. ``a**b`` of two ints may return a floating point type,
+#. ``a**b`` of one or more non-complex floating point numbers may end
+   up return a complex number.

comment_data.body: Maybe just `type_was_inferred`? IIUC, the intention is to allow readjustments during coercion if we're in a grey area that allows some degree of freedom. Is that correct?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12225,6 +12229,22 @@ def py_operation_function(self, code):
 class PowNode(NumBinopNode):
     #  '**' operator.
 
+    cpow = None
+    cpow_false_changed_result_type = False  # was the result type affected by cpow==False

comment_data.body:
Yes that is correct. The idea was that if the user hasn't explicitly specified `cpow` then we interpret:

```
cdef double x = a**b
```

as "they almost certainly want the old cpow behaviour". And give a warning advising them to explicitly specify it.

I think `type_was_inferred` is reasonable with an explanatory comment

```suggestion

    the behaviour matched the ``cpow=True`` version.
```

(or spell "Cython 3.0" vs. "Cython 3" consistently)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -864,6 +864,24 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     division is performed with negative operands.  See `CEP 516
     <https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/enhancements-division>`_.  Default is
     False.
+    
+``cpow`` (True / False)
+    ``cpow`` has modifies the return type of ``a**b``, as shown in the
+    table below:
+    
+        .. csv-table:: cpow behaviour
+            :file: cpow_table.csv
+            :header-rows: 1
+            :class: longtable
+            :widths: 1 1 3 3
+    
+    The ``cpow==True`` behaviour largely keeps the result type the
+    same as the operand types, while the ``cpow==False`` behaviour
+    follows Python and returns a flexible type depending on the
+    inputs.
+
+    Introduced in Cython 3.0 with a default of False;
+    before Cython 3 the behaviour matched the ``cpow=True`` version.

comment_data.body: Are the differences (between False and None) observable from a user PoV? If so, the description in `docs/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.rst` should mention that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -187,6 +187,8 @@ def copy_inherited_directives(outer_directives, **new_directives):
     'auto_pickle': None,
     'cdivision': False,  # was True before 0.12
     'cdivision_warnings': False,
+    'cpow': None,  # was True before 3.0
+    # None (not set by user) is treated as slightly different from False

comment_data.body:
They probably are observable if you look closely. The difference is that `None` second-guesses a few cases where the user probably did intend the old behaviour:

```
cdef double z = x**y  # uses the old "return a double" behaviour
cdef_function_taking_a_double(x**y)  # uses the old "return a double" behaviour
```

It issues a warning when it does this though. It isn't possible for the user to manually set it to None though, so they can't choose this behaviour.

I'd originally chosen not to document this - it was fairly fiddly to explain anyway and I don't think we really want people coding for this behaviour, but I can reconsider.

If we did document it then possible the section on migrating to Cython 3 would be the place to do it, since it's mainly a migration aid.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -187,6 +187,8 @@ def copy_inherited_directives(outer_directives, **new_directives):
     'auto_pickle': None,
     'cdivision': False,  # was True before 0.12
     'cdivision_warnings': False,
+    'cpow': None,  # was True before 3.0
+    # None (not set by user) is treated as slightly different from False

commit.message:
Fix bug with complex powers of negative numbers

A shortcut was incorrectly applied that returned NaN instead
of an imaginary number

title: Add the `cpow` directive to bring Cython `**` close to Python
